patterns: How is mean different from median?
responses: Mean is the average of a dataset. It is calculated by adding all values and dividing by the total number of values.
Median is the middle value of a dataset when arranged in ascending or descending order. It is useful when data contains outliers.
Mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset. A dataset can have one mode, multiple modes, or no mode.
Range is the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a dataset. It measures spread.
Variance measures how far each data point is from the mean. It shows how spread out the data is.

patterns: Difference between variance and standard deviation
responses: Standard deviation is the square root of variance. It measures how much data deviates from the mean.
Skewness measures the asymmetry of a distribution. Positive skew means the right tail is longer. Negative skew means the left tail is longer.
Kurtosis measures the tailedness of a distribution. High kurtosis means heavy tails, low kurtosis means light tails.
Quartiles divide data into four equal parts. Q1 is the 25th percentile, Q2 is the median, and Q3 is the 75th percentile.
Interquartile Range (IQR) is the difference between Q3 and Q1. It measures the spread of the middle 50% of data.
Probability measures the likelihood of an event occurring. It ranges from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).
Conditional probability is the probability of an event occurring given that another event has already occurred.

patterns: Difference between independent and dependent events
responses: Independent events do not affect each other's probability. Dependent events influence the probability of each other.
A random variable represents numerical outcomes of a random experiment. It can be discrete or continuous.
Expected value is the weighted average of all possible values of a random variable.

patterns: Difference between descriptive and inferential statistics
Role of inferential statistics in data science
responses: Inferential statistics uses sample data to make conclusions about a population. It helps in hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, and predictions.

patterns: Why sample is used instead of population?
responses: Population refers to the entire group of interest, while a sample is a subset of the population used for analysis.

patterns: Difference between probability and non probability sampling
responses: Sampling methods are techniques used to select a subset from a population. Common methods include simple random sampling, stratified sampling, cluster sampling, and systematic sampling.
Sampling distribution is the probability distribution of a statistic (like mean) obtained from multiple samples of the same population.

patterns: Role of CLT in machine learning
responses: Central Limit Theorem states that the sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches a normal distribution as sample size increases, regardless of population distribution.
Null hypothesis (H0) states that there is no significant difference or effect. It is assumed true until evidence suggests otherwise.

patterns: Difference between null and alternative hypothesis
responses: Alternative hypothesis (H1) states that there is a significant difference or effect. It is accepted if null hypothesis is rejected.

patterns: What does p less than 0.05 mean?
responses: P-value is the probability of observing results as extreme as the sample results assuming null hypothesis is true. If p < 0.05, results are statistically significant.
Type 1 error occurs when we reject a true null hypothesis. It is also called false positive.
Type 2 error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis. It is also called false negative.
A confidence interval provides a range of values within which the true population parameter is expected to lie with a certain confidence level.

patterns: Difference between z test and t test
responses: Z-test is used to test hypotheses when population variance is known and sample size is large (n > 30).
T-test is used to compare means when sample size is small and population variance is unknown.

patterns: Difference between ANOVA and t test
responses: ANOVA stands for Analysis of Variance. It is used to compare means of three or more groups.
Chi-square test is used to determine if there is a significant association between categorical variables.

patterns: Relation between power and type 2 error
responses: Statistical power is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis. Higher power reduces Type 2 error.
Covariance measures the direction of relationship between two variables. If covariance is positive, variables move in the same direction. If negative, they move in opposite directions.
Correlation measures both the strength and direction of relationship between two variables. It ranges from -1 to +1. +1 means perfect positive correlation, -1 means perfect negative correlation.

patterns: How is covariance different from correlation?
responses: Covariance shows direction of relationship but does not standardize the scale. Correlation standardizes covariance and always lies between -1 and 1, making it easier to interpret.

patterns: What is bias in machine learning?
What is variance in machine learning?
Overfitting and underfitting relation to bias variance
responses: Bias-Variance Tradeoff explains the balance between model simplicity and complexity. High bias leads to underfitting, while high variance leads to overfitting. The goal is to minimize total error by balancing both.

patterns: How to reduce bias in ML?
responses: High bias occurs when a model is too simple and fails to capture underlying patterns. It leads to underfitting.

patterns: How to reduce variance in ML?
responses: High variance occurs when a model learns noise from training data and performs poorly on unseen data. It leads to overfitting.

patterns: Explain Central Limit Theorem in detail
responses: Central Limit Theorem states that when independent samples are drawn from any distribution, the sampling distribution of the sample mean approaches a normal distribution as sample size increases (usually n â‰¥ 30), regardless of the original population distribution. This is fundamental for confidence intervals and hypothesis testing.

patterns: What are TP TN FP FN?
responses: A confusion matrix is a table used to evaluate classification models. It contains True Positives (TP), True Negatives (TN), False Positives (FP), and False Negatives (FN).
Accuracy measures the proportion of correct predictions. Formula: (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN).
Precision measures how many predicted positive cases are actually positive. Formula: TP / (TP + FP).
Recall measures how many actual positive cases were correctly identified. Formula: TP / (TP + FN).

patterns: Difference between accuracy and F1 score
responses: F1 score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall. It balances both metrics and is useful for imbalanced datasets.
ROC curve plots True Positive Rate vs False Positive Rate. AUC measures overall classification performance. Higher AUC means better model performance.
